entry.et: Middle English shetten, shutten, from Old English scyttan; akin to Middle Dutch schutten to shut in, Old English scēotan to shoot shoot

def.dt: :to move into position to close an opening shut the lid
:to prevent entrance to or passage to or from
:to confine by or as if by enclosure shut herself in her study
:to fasten with a lock or bolt
:to close by bringing enclosing or covering parts together shut the eyes
:to cause to cease or suspend an operation or activity often used with down
:to close itself or become closed flowers that shut at night
:to cease or suspend an operation or activity often used with down
:closed, fastened, or folded together
:rid clear free usually used with of
:the act of shutting
:to settle so as to obscure vision :close in the night shut down early
:to make ineffective in competition shut down the opposition's offensive line
:sleep get some shut–eye
:confine enclose
:to prevent production of (oil or gas) by closing down a well
:a person who is confined to home, a room, or bed because of illness or incapacity
:a narrow gorge-shaped part of an otherwise wide valley
:available oil or gas which is not being produced from an existing well
:confined to one's home or an institution by illness or incapacity
:secretive brooding a bitter, shut–in face Claudia Cassidy
:tending to avoid social contact :withdrawn the shut–in personality type S. K. Weinberg
:to close off :separate usually used with from shut off from the rest of the world
:to cut off (as flow or passage) :stop shuts off the oxygen supply
:to stop the operation of (as a machine) shut the motor off
:to cease operating :stop shuts off automatically
:exclude
:to prevent (an opponent) from scoring in a game or contest
:to forestall the bidding of (bridge opponents) by making a high or preemptive bid
